creator: jayajith.a.mani@gmail.com
text:
Our application used to have weblogic servers before we switched to websphere 
servers. As we know that weblogic does not have a java of its own so we used 
Sun Java but Webshpere has IBM java along with it.

We fear that this change in the Java version has caused something to go wrong 
in the configurations of the log4jconfig.xml because of which we do not 
control the logging of the application

Please respond asap.

creator: carnold@apache.org
text:
This is a usage question and should be asked on log4j-user (or an appropriate Websphere forum) where 
you will more likely get a timely response.  Before filing a bug report, you should have at least a suspicion 
that there is a bug in the code and provide enough information for the developers to have a chance to find 
it.  We are good, but we are not psychic.

log4j would not automatically look for log4config.xml (it looks for log4j.xml), so if you were reading 
log4config.xml, so someone was telling it to look in a non-default location.  You could see what happens 
if you provide a log4j.xml file instead.

creator: lauredo@gmail.com
text:
First of all, "WebLogic" also has a JDK of its own, called JRockit.

Then, in WebLogic server, you have a property to specify the log4j configuration
file, named LOG4J_CONFIG_FILE in setDomainEnv.sh

The lines that set it are:

if [ "${LOG4J_CONFIG_FILE}" != "" ] ; then
	JAVA_PROPERTIES="${JAVA_PROPERTIES}
-Dlog4j.configuration=file:${LOG4J_CONFIG_FILE}"
	export JAVA_PROPERTIES
fi

So if it was set in WebLogic server, it's perfectly normal it doesn't work
anymore in Websphere.

HTH
